question: Question_02_(b)_iii
statement:
Using Euler's method, determine \emph{y\textsubscript{1}},
\emph{y\textsubscript{2}}, \emph{y\textsubscript{3}} for
\emph{y\textsubscript{0} = 1} and $\Delta t = 1/2$

\begin{align*}\frac{dy}{dt} = 3y-y^2\end{align*}
sols:
By Euler's method, we can determine an approximation for the values
$y_{n} = y(n\Delta t)$ by the formula,

\begin{align*}
y_{n+1} &= y_{n} + \Delta t\,f(y_{n}), \quad f(y) = 3y - y^{2} \\
&= y_{n} + \Delta t \, (3y_{n} - y_{n}^{2})\end{align*} Thus, to determine $y_{1}$ we evaluate the following:

\begin{align*}
y_{1} &= y_{0} + \Delta t \,(3y_{0} - y_{0}^{2})\\
&= 1 + (1/2)(3 - 1^{2})\\
&= 2.\end{align*} Applying Euler's method for the following two steps, we
get $y_{2}$...

\begin{align*}
y_{2} &= y_{1} + \Delta t \,(3y_{1} - y_{1}^{2})\\
&= 2 + (1/2)(6 - 2^{2})\\
&= 3.\end{align*} and $y_{3}$...

\begin{align*}
y_{3} &= y_{2} + \Delta t \,(3y_{2} - y_{2}^{2})\\
&= 3 + (1/2)(9 - 3^{2})\\
&= 3.\end{align*} Therefore,

\begin{align*}{\color{blue}y_{1} = 2, \,y_{2} = 3, \,y_{3} =3}\end{align*}
hints:
Remember that $y_{n} = y(n \Delta t)$.

If you are unsure about how to proceed, you might try reviewing this
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_method\#Example}{example of
using Euler's method}. (In the example, $h$ is equivalent to $\Delta t$
of our problem).
